results: Theorems on coexistence of Einstein metrics with Ricci flat metrics
title: Einstein Constants and Smooth Topology.pdf
abstract: It was ﬁrst shown in [10] that certain high-dimensional smooth closed manifolds admit pairs of Einstein metrics with Ricci curvatures of opposite sign. After reviewing subsequent progress that has been made on this topic, we then prove various related results, with the ultimate goal of stimulating further research on associated questions. 1 Introduction A Riemannian metric g is said to be Einstein if its Ricci curvature, considered as a function on the unit tangent bundle, is constant. This is of course equivalent to requiring that the Ricci tensor r of g satisfy r = λg (1) for some real number λ. In the original context of general relativity, where the metric is taken to be Lorentzian rather than Riemannian, equation (1) is called the Einstein vacuum equation with cosmological constant. In fact, Einstein did brieﬂy consider the possibility that the constant λ in (1) might be non-zero, but he eventually [22, p. 44] came to consider this idea to be “the biggest blunder of his life.” It must therefore surely be considered to be amusingly ironic that we mathematicians have acquired the habit of calling λ the Einstein constant of a Riemannian metric g satisfying (1). ∗Supported in part by NSF grant DMS-2203572. 1
